misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that saving the last element, shifting elements from right to left (copying arr[i-1] into arr[i]), then placing the saved last element into arr[0] will perform a one-position right shift with wrap-around.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no conceptual gap here: this matches Java’s array indexing and assignment semantics, and the loop direction avoids overwriting values before they are copied.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error; produces correct output for all relevant cases (n==0 prints just "Shifted: ", n==1 leaves array unchanged, n>1 rotates correctly).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that to shift elements to the right, they should iterate backwards through the array from the last element toward the first, copying each element to the position of the next element (arr[i] = arr[i-1]). They think this forward-copying approach will correctly shift all elements rightward.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has implemented a left shift rather than a right shift. When iterating backwards and executing arr[i] = arr[i-1], this copies the element at position i-1 into position i, which shifts elements leftward through the array. For a right shift, elements at position i should move to position i+1. The student's mental model confuses the direction of data movement with the iteration direction—iterating backwards does not automatically produce a rightward shift.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that by saving the last element before the loop and then restoring it to arr[0] after shifting all other elements leftward, the overall effect will be a right shift. They think: save last → shift everything left → put saved element at front = right shift.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: This is a compound error. The shift loop itself implements a left shift (arr[i] = arr[i-1]). Saving and restoring the last element cannot compensate for an incorrectly-implemented shift direction. The student appears to understand that the last element should wrap to the front, but they fundamentally misunderstand how to achieve an actual right shift. For a true right shift, the element at index i should move to index i+1; the saved last element naturally goes to index 0. The student's approach would turn [1,2,3,4] into [4,1,2,3] only by accident if the shift loop worked correctly, but their shift loop is backwards.
